I see the point of the video, but I don’t think it does much to alleviate the feeling generated by the segments in question. There are other ways to point out how people have misconceptions without a “man on the street” type interview. And the way you do it is very much seeing yourself up as counter to the misconception. It paints you as superior, and given that you’re the visual focal point of most of your videos, it paints the interviewee (who usually doesn’t get the chance to redeem themselves in the videos) as being so dumb they aren’t worth the time to teach. They’re a straw man for the lesson.

A better way to do that might be to set yourself up as the straw man. I’m sure I’ve seen videos where you have already done this. Setting up an anecdote where you present the misconception as something you’ve held that you had to let go when presented with scientific evidence to the contrary.

Pointing at a person and saying “this person thinks a wrong thing, let me tell you the right thing” distances the audience and yourself from the humility of being wrong and learning to change their perspective in a way that hurts the way you come off to the viewers.

Now I am triggered 😂😂, don't sweat it dude I was married to a woman who thought everything I said was to insult her, when in fact I was trying to let her explain things and come to the right conclusion herself, like the mid wive technique propagated by Socrates (I am not sure about this and you can correct me if I am wrong, I will not feel stupid or be insulted if you do), but basically the principle was not to give the answer but ask the same question the person had in so many parts that the conclusion sprang out naturally, like a midwife helping a mother to give birth naturally. But to her it sounded condescending, as if I was ridiculing her, and it always ended up in a fight until she heard me on the phone helping someone with his computer problem in the same way, and she asked wasn't that person annoyed or insulted, and I said no, this helped him enormously, he understood the problem himself and fixed it himself, in the end he had a good feeling about himself because HE SOLVED IT HIMSELF, I only asked annoying parts of the whole question, turning them in to small solvable segments, providing a step by step tool to come to the full solution. She suddenly realized how getting angry wasn't helpfull at all and that I was not condescending but instead tried to teach her how to solve problems in the future, and although we are divorced for several other reasons, she managed to solve quite some complex computer problems by herself, of which i am actually proud of her and I told her this. But people who do not know this or your technique and have been ridiculed their entire life might take it as offensive simply because they aren't trained in thinking for themselves, a basic question like: "Did you try turning it off and on again", can sometimes put them in a blind rage and it sounds like I think you are stupid, but this is a process often forgotten, it is a necessary step in the chain and it does need to be checked first, I do rephrase my question to "You probably already tried restarting?", giving them the feeling that I think they are intelligent and that they are smart enough, and when they didn't I usually get a response like "OMG why didn't I think of that, it's so simple I forgot, let's try that".
So maybe the thing to help you is to rephrase some of your questions, at least you are not like Jay Leno interviewing people and only showing the dumbest people, maybe people should check him out first, now those where some "Rocket scientists right there". Also maybe ask them what their background is, if you have no idea what chemistry is you won't even know what H or O means and that is OK, and you can comfort them by saying this and explaining it to them. Pretty sure an english lit balletdancer will not know the answers to it, doesn't mean they are stupid, they know more about english lit and if you want fries with that burger than you do....Ooops time to leave

"What is water you may ask? Well... That would have been my answer ;D" Its chemical formula H2O, indicates that each of its molecules contains one oxygen and two hydrogen atoms, connected by covalent bonds. The hydrogen atoms are attached to the oxygen atom at an angle of 104.45°. Water, to answer your question, is an inorganic, transparent, tasteless, odorless, and nearly colorless chemical substance, which is the main constituent of Earth's hydrosphere and the fluids of all known living organisms (in which it acts as a solvent). It is vital for all known forms of life, even though it provides no calories or organic nutrients. But here its to be said that "Water" is only the name of the liquid state of H2O at standard conditions for temperature and pressure.

Plants give out CO2 all the time, it is just that in the day they take more in to produce glucose during photosynthesis. At night while no photosynthesis occurs, they give out CO2 but don't take any in. glucose + oxygen → carbon dioxide + water (+ energy).
What plants are really good at is storing that CO2 as growth while they are living and before the things decompose and release all that carbon as CO2 and methane. So DEAD trees (especially firewood and coal) are net emitters of CO2. All that carbon doesn't just disappear as many people seem to believe.

There are a lot of comments here that some things are just basic knowledge/facts that every person should know, and it's a sign that education systems are failing if one can't answer, for example, the chemical composition of water, or what not. Don't get me wrong, i'm shocked if someone doesn't know that, but a lot of these things are really more akin to trivia. Like, even if 99% of some populace knows that water is H2O, that doesn't mean they have any real understanding (myself included) of chemical bonds, or why that structure grants water the properties it has.

I used to assume that most people know the dinosaurs got wiped out around 65 million years ago, as that number has come up so much in random pop culture through my life. But talking with a co-worker a dozen or more years older than me, she had no idea, and pointed out that when she was younger dinosaurs simply weren't as relevant in the popular imagination.

Or, i'd wager any reasonably educated american knows that e=mc^2 and knows what those terms represent, but if you ask them to explain why the energy of kilo of water is more than a cup's worth, or just... what does that equation really mean, they'd be at a loss. I live in china, and people here tend to know e=mc^2, but more than half have no idea what 'c' represents, and when i tell them it's the speed of light they look at me like i'm crazy, and are sure that i'm mistaken. But then there are other random facts that permeate the culture here and i don't recall ever learning, or don't see any importance to (no examples come to mind).

I think all this says way more about what an individual commenter values w/r/t education/knowledge. E.g. i believe any educated person should absolutely know a basic timeline of: age of the universe/earth/life/mammals/hominids/humans/civilization, and i'm flummoxed when an otherwise smart person has no idea whether hominids have been around for 50,000 years or a million or a hundred million or billion, but that person might have a much better grasp of the development of political philosophy or comparative religion or any other topic that they'd just as rightly fault me for not knowing enough about.

We should get over ourselves, a little, is my point.

There are, in theory, four basic categories of knowledge (basic Punnett square): 1) you know what you know 2) you know what you don't know 3) you don't know what you know and 4) you don't know what you don't know. In reality only numbers 3 and 4 are truly correct. Numbers 1 and 2 are actually dependent on your own willingness to admit you are wrong or don't know. As was implied in the video, most of the time ignorance isn't a willful state of being, we are simply unaware that we are ignorant in the first place. The danger of this type of ignorance is that we are so unaware of our ignorance that we "tune out" when we assume that we already know. This is an application of confirmation bias. We have a statement or "fact" that we believe is true about a subject, so whenever we are asked to confirm this or are taught the subject again, we, secure in our "knowledge" of the subject, subconsciously don't put as much "value" in the discussion or lesson due to the fact that we believe it is merely reinforcing our beliefs. This is a state of close-mindedness that keeps us from learning the correct information even if we are taught it multiple times. Learning requires a state of open-mindedness and for most people this is a very difficult state to put themselves into. The entire idea of starting a lesson/video with the misconceptions is meant simply to shock us into that state of open-mindedness so that we can give our full attention to the lesson and actually learn, even if we were correct in the first place, the idea or its applications in the real world.

Another aspect of these misconceptions is to try to show us that in reality we know a lot more than we realize (number 3 from above), we just haven't been able to make the jump from the "cold" science to the "real world application." A good example of this is one of the Veritasium videos about the temperature of a metal object vs a book. As was alluded to in the video, many people actually do know that metal is a better thermal conductor but aren't able to make the jump from the theoretical knowledge to the real world application, especially in the face of what they are experiencing, which is that when they touch the metal, it feels colder than the book.

Finally, let's get to number 4 from above. We don't know what we don't know. This is possibly the most important, yet subtle benefit of these misconception busting videos. Being shown that the world is much more complicated than we realize, or being forced to look at what we don't understand leads us down a path of questioning. Even if after watching the video and actually learning the information, by constantly being shown there is more to learn and our lack of understanding of the world around us, we begin questioning our own "real world experience," why things are the way they are, and what is left to learn. These are the fundamental questions that begin any person's journey down the path towards truth. Not perceived truth but actual truth; the type that lasts forever.

Why do we watch a TV show like Jeopardy? It's not to learn, although usually we do learn something that sticks in our brains. Most of us watch for those occasions that we actually know the answer before the contestants say it. It's even better if we know the answer and none of the contestants get it right! That's why we watch this type of "idiots on the street" videos. It re-affirms to ourselves that we do indeed have knowledge; that our own education actually accomplished something. These videos also show an underlying problem (not really the point of the videos of Vertasium - I don't think) in our education system when college age adults can't answer a question that should have been learned in 7th grade science. These people aren't dumb, they were failed by an education system that has turned to emphasizing self esteem ("no one fails") rather than fundamental learning.

The most important thing that these videos show is that these people CAN learn when the explanation or facts are given to them. They aren't dumb, they were pushed through school whether they knew the answers or not.

I don't think you make them look stupid, but I'm a science teacher. I recognise common misconceptions.

 It's the VIEWER who makes the judgement "stupid". In a similar way that "beauty is in the eye of the beholder", people INTERPRET wrong answers as "stupid". But mistakes are not stupid; they are opportunities to learn. A person who doesn't make mistakes doesn't learn.

But so many of us have been through an education system which has taught us otherwise. In my school copying is rampant because, in close relation to the excellent Veritasium “Learned Helplessness”, the pupils are terrified of LOSING MARKS by making mistakes. As a result, they learn well below their potential. If you stop viewing mistakes as dumb, then you’ll learn more, faster.

Conclusion: stop viewing mistakes as dumb.

PLANTS ARE ALSO LIVING THINGS. THEY DO EMIT carbon dioxide BECAUSE THEY RESPIRE as OTHER LIVING BEINGS. SO THEY EMIT CO2 too. But as for preparation of their food (photosynthesis) oxygen comes out at a huge byproduct of their food synthesis that it overshadows the amount of CO2 which is also produced in the same time( daytime) because they respire. That is why people say don't keep plants in your bedroom because when you go to sleep and turn the lights off they don't synthesis their food and produce oxygen BUT ONLY RESPIRE which produces JUST Carbon dioxide ! When people call you pretentious for making other people look stupid by exposing false beliefs they hold, they are implicitly making a value judgement that says that being wrong about something means that person is generally stupid, and that being wrong is bad and makes you a bad person in a way. It's like the fundamental attribution error. I think this is a common cultural belief about being and wrong and making mistakes. But the thing is, being wrong about something isn't necessarily bad and doesn't make you stupid; it's how you approach being wrong that matters. Do you examine your own beliefs and do your best to uncover and overcome the false ones? That's what's important. And as a teacher, I get the same smile you do when a student says something wrong. It's a teachable moment! It's an opportunity to help them become better, more knowledgable, and smarter by examining the world and their understanding of it. I think you're doing great work, man. And as for people calling you pretentious, I hope they understand that being wrong and exposing ignorance are not bad things if you approach them as learning opportunities, but trying to shame someone for doing so is like fighting on behalf of ignorance.

I had a math teacher, may she rest in piece, that when i changed schools (keep in mind I was hell of a smart kid back in 7th grade) on the first lesson asked me a question and when i could not answer it straight up wrote me a negative grade. For the 13 year old me, that was a shock, how could i fail, how could i looks so stupid, and i made a promise to my self that I will never feel that shame and humiliation again, before I went to math again and the same thing repeated it self. It felt as if the teacher just smelled my fear, and in her line of questioning always picked the topics i had the worst understanding of. Then instead of focusing on the fact that i failed, I started noticing the bigger picture, that teacher did not fail me or anyone out of spite, she wanted us to learn that failing and looking stupid in most cases is a good thing, that it can be a drive, and a motivation to get a deeper understanding of things.. In the end math was one of the lowest average grades i got, but due to her teachings, i was forced to look into things, to explore things that i may have not chosen to learn, had i gotten a good grade. in the end the low grades ended up meaning absolutely nothing, as i passed my State math exam with flying colors. I only pity the truly stupid people who neglected the lesson, and blamed the teacher for giving them bad marks, instead of accepting the fact that they will never truly know everything, and that not knowing something is a joy, as you have still so much more of the world to explore and understand.

Hey there. Some (many)) thoughts.
I think the main problem is not with the stupidity of people in the video, but with the content itself. (Sorry for maybe bad english)

It's true, in my opinion, that the best way to teach a person, is to ask him questions. To make him find the answer himself. And, probably, many of those people that you've interviewed will remember what they've learned. But... will the viewers? It is entertaining and learnable, when you're the one being asked, but you don't really ask the viewers. We just watch how other people say predictably wrong answers, while at the same time yearning for the right ones. For me it creates a feeling of frustrastion, like when you're forced to watch the whole video just for that cool stuff at the end - a topic that you brought up yourself in your video about starting youtube channel. No matter why those people act like that and how you treat it, basically, half of your videos are about wrong or stupid talk, and that's what creating the reaction I think. Half of the content is not about learning, but about unknowing. You've probably thought about this a lot with your PHD, but maybe you should ask yourself this: how entertaining and interesting it is to watch someone giving the wrong answers, when you've opened the video in order to hear the right ones? For me - it's not. The only thing I'm learning from this is how many people there are that don't know the answers, and what can they come up with while trying to find them. And that's not what I, personally, would like to see in educational videos.

And by the way... you DID basically sad, that trees get most of their mass from carbon dioxide) You just showed us a bunch of stupid talk before that. You didn't even explain the process.

Getting back to "interviewing the viewers", I like the way Mike Stevens does this. He leads the viewer from the start, asking the most basic and obvious questions FOR him - the ones that most of the pepole would have thought of themselfs - and then answers them immediately.

I like yout entusiasm, I like the energy, with which you say and do things, and I like the intent and goal of this channel. And really respect that. Just wanted to share some thoughts about the content, because I think it's important)

How, exactly, does it qualify as "making people look stupid" if all you do is ask them a question?  Aren't they making themselves look stupid?  Anyone who is bothered and think it might happen to them should do 2 simple things:  Do not say things that you don't believe to be true.  Just say "I don't know" if you don't know what elements water is made of or what organisms emit CO2.  Number two: Learn stuff.  Actual stuff.  Don't just trust random things you hear people say, ask questions and find out why they say those things.  If they can't explain it, then put that into the "maybe, but I still don't KNOW" category and don't repeat it until you have been able to verify it.  Done!   Another bonus thing, which will make you an amazing person and result in everyone thinking you are smart (because you will end up being smart): When someone shows you that you are wrong, THANK THEM.  Don't get embarrassed!  When you find out that you are wrong about X, you never have to be wrong about X again... ever!  For the rest of your entire life!  That's a GOOD thing, no matter how wrong you were before!

Two of the most profound driving forces of man is desire and fear. Humiliation plays on both. You fear not only being wrong, but fear being ostracized from your peers. You fear being looked down upon. You also desire to look down on others, its the desire for power/dominance in everyone. You desire to be correct, you desire being accepted. Humans particularly remember bad, uncomfortable or scary situations as an evolutionary trait so you can avoid it in the future.
We also remember our desires and interests and fears over that which we care little about. Humiliation sticks in our mind more then most other things because it plays on both fear and desire. It can help you learn because of this, but it depends on who humiliates you and why. If you don't care about the subject or the people humiliating you then you are less likely to be affected. If your friend humiliates you and its a subject you care about then it will have a profound affect. This is based yet again on fear and desire. If you desire to fit in with that person, you'll adapt, if you don't you won't. Fear and desire can explain lots of human behavior.

Or to make a political point (i.e. make the other political party look stupid).

You could easily start with interviews for your research, but instead of airing footage that people will find embarrassing because they have been caught off guard on the street by a question, consider instead using your friends as actors, or even what a few vloggers have done, and dress themselves in different costumes, and work through the dialogues that way. Create a composite character or two. As long as you don't adopt insultingly caricatured or stereotyped behaviors for the "unknowledgeable" person, you're probably going to be OK.

Galileo had the right general approach in the Dialogue...though naming a character "Simplicio" does lack a bit in tact, as opposed to conveying the assumption you seek to, that an intelligent person can be uninformed.

Never even realized people got so up in arms about Veritasium, but... I (for one) think the channel is pretty amazing work.  It's entertaining, organized, thought-provoking, and pretty damn efficient with all of it!  I couldn't pull this off, lol!!!

Beyond all that... I hate to say it, but... even IF (let's just pretend) someone IS a pretentious D-bag...

...but they are factually CORRECT and are essentially spouting/wielding truth, and doling out solid verification of things that basically aren't open to much opinion/perspective...

...hard as it may be, one really needs to ~listen~ and to consider that information--regardless of the way they might "rub you the wrong way".

I once had a teacher who was SUCH A JERK.  So rude... so mean... so snooty and just generally boring, negative, monotone, and overly book-smart (but not street smart)...

...BUT STILL.  There was a lot of stuff he said that I couldn't refute unless I had decided to be blinded by how much he bothered me.

In the end, for me, it became about truth & fact vs. beliefs and fiction.  And I don't care if a 600 lb. sweaty Mexican guy with three eyes and bad breath gives me the facts... or a 36-24-36 blonde with a soft voice.

Sure, I might RATHER one "delivery" over the other... but if the information remains the same... who cares.  Grow up.  ;)

Actually, the Oriental fellow was partially correct.  Trees DO emit carbon dioxide, when it's dark.  The net result, of course, is they remove more carbon during the day than they add at night, but he was at least partially correct.  Most people do not know that.

Also, I find it funny people call things good for nature "green".  Particularly carbon emissions.  Plants love more carbon dioxide, and grow faster with it.  Not only that, if things warm up, the growing season is made longer, so they grow for longer periods of time. 

But, more importantly, most plants don't like green light - that's why they reflect it.  They prefer the more abundant red, and the higher energy blue.

I think debunking common "wisdom" is one of the most useful ways of teaching. But strangely, we have this disdain for being shown wrong. This is especially true when we've invested a lot into those false beliefs. Sometimes we feel embarrassed so much to the point where some people will absolutely defend a point of view that has clearly been shown wrong. This extends to watching people being shown wrong being considered rude.

Perhaps the best way to do it without looking like a douche is to introduce anonymity to the people who you are correcting. In the world of Sociology, Emile Durkheim wrote with this kind of strategy. He wrote of a question that needed an answer, proposed a few of the answers that many people have given, then proved them false. After that, he proposed his own answer that fits best. The reader was corrected privately.

Personally I'm not intimidated nor offended by anything I've seen in these videos.  I admit that I've learned quite a bit from the videos here.  I genuinely enjoy the interviews and questions he asks of those on his videos.  

I have always believed strongly that the first step to learning is to admit we either don't know or are simply wrong in what we do know.  Without this admission the next step of asking for answers makes little sense or difference.  Learning starts with the admission, "I don't know."  

As far as the interviews on these videos, I've always seen these interviews and answers--regardless of how silly or incorrect they may be--as a handful of volunteers willing to make that first step of admission for us, the viewers, so that we can sit in the privacy of our own home and not be humbled publicly by our own admissions.  Quite often I simply don't know either, but would much prefer someone else admit it so I don't look silly.  Besides, it's easier to laugh with someone else than at ourselves.

I feel the videos here to be well presented, informative, and even humorous.  Never once have my sensibilities been so sensitive that I've found even a shred of offense.

I'm inclined to add that without misconceptions, there can be no sense of wonder in this world.  I have, time and time again, been proven wrong by the things I have learned, but there is no shame in removing ignorance from your own or someone else's life.  The vast majority of people are conditioned to provide and answer, even if wrong, in lieu if making the more honest statement of, "I don't know."  

Those that are incorrect in these videos are not berated, ridiculed or chastised.  In fact, many of them, when given the evidence, appear truly fascinated and even grateful their misconception was stood on its head.  

Please continue doing what you do.  You provide an entertaining spin to science, as well as inroads to tangential learning.  I imagine many of those you interview research the topic further.  I have done so after watching several of your videos.  To inspire a person to seek out information is the mark of a good educator.

I think the main issue is the simple questions you discuss in many if your videos. For example, "Can you go the speed of light?" has an obvious answer; only if you are massless or have infinite energy. These questions are really very easy and it seems not challenging enough.

Personally, asking people questions about physics and chemistry in public is a generally healthy practice, it makes people feel a bit embarrassed and gets them to learn new things, as you have said.

+Veritasium Its quite entertaining to watch peoples misconceptions, I thought that was why you did your videos like that. If it genuinely is as you say to teach people, then I think it would be interesting to try the following strategies:

1) Pretend like you've stopped filming. I think people can get a little bit flustered when being filmed and then they either say "I don't know" or are afraid of suggesting something unintuative for fear of being wrong. You could just say "Cut", but carry on the interview.

2) Pretend that you don't actually know the correct answer, but continue to ask questions. So perhaps they would say "Trees are made from water, soil, and sunlight" and you would reply "Yeah that sounds right, but I feel that there must be something else, I am just not sure what it could be." "what happens when you burn a tree?", "what other things burn?", "is charcoal made from trees?", "what is that black sooty stuff?", "do you eat carbs?" "what foods are good sources of carbs?" "do you know what the word 'carbs' is short for?"

3) Ask more different questions, In most of your interviews I see this pattern where you feel as though the interviewee is really close to the answer but they don't actually say the right word. You want them to get it right, but keep asking the same question in the hope that it will suddenly click. I think you need to ask different questions so that perhaps they look at it from a different perspective.

4) I like that you don't give away the answer, but by pretending to be dumb, I think people would be more likely to get the answer right instead of just waiting for you to tell them the answer. I think most people expect you to give them the answer in the end because of the format of the interview. Besides, by downplaying yourself you will come across as less of a douche ;)

Hey Veritasium, I just wanted to say that I really appreciate the approach you take to science and teaching. I often wish more people would adopt this approach when it comes to providing knowledge in general. I think you're a great person and as overbearingly affectionate as this may seem: your existence is a kindness to humanity. Not knowing something isn't what makes someone stupid, refusing to admit that you don't know something is what makes someone stupid.

~Sincerely, A man of science in the making.

I actually agree with what Veritasium does. I am a college student and I can see how many people just memorize concepts from high school and really struggle to understand more complex ones. When people are asked questions they don't know, it actually helps them learn more and remember the concepts in the long run. However, if they memorize the ideas without thinking about them, they will eventually forget what they learned. Research even shows this to be true. Veritasium does make a point. Not everybody will be an expert or necessarily know physics well, but he does a good job compared to most channels. The fact that he goes around asking people about science concepts will actually give viewers a better and broader aspect of how a concept can be applied because as one can see, people already have misconceptions about the most basic aspects in science that make up all of the much complicated ones.  One can learn from people's responses and mistakes. This is a part of what makes us human. If one never learns from their mistakes, then one never makes progress. People should be thanking Veritasium not criticizing him.

The people who say that these videos "make people look stupid" don't understand the joys of teaching.  Revealing people's assumptions, biases, and misconceptions is part of the process of effective learning.  I use the same techniques in my economics classes.  It's not about making people look stupid or taking pleasure in people's lack of knowledge in a specific area, it's about "the reveal" as I like to call it.  It feels really good to HELP someone realize they had a bias or misconception in the first place because it helps them question.  Hopefully it will make them more humble, too.

As far as I know, trees DO emit CO2. They do it whenever they are not photosynthetising. Like every night, when there isn't enough light, or at winter when they lose their leaves. In order to keep their metabolism going, and basically stay alive, they need to burn some of the energy (in the form of carbohydrates, like sugar) they have accumulated during the photosynthesis phase, and that produces CO2. They only burn just enough to stay alive though, so their O2 output is way bigger overall.

In order to explain an extremely complicated and abstract concept that exists outside our human experience, we have to resort to using similes and other literary devices. The Bible does this very well. It's actually one of the interesting evidences that it is Divinely Inspired. A great deal of the Bible was written by shepherds and fishermen. Yet the literary devices used by these shepherds and fishermen are difficult to master, even for literature students.

You know the difference by understanding language, humanity, and putting yourself in the shoes of the person who is writing. When Jesus said "I am the door," He isn't physically a door. He's using a literary device. But the literary device is being used to explain a very REAL spiritual concept. So Jesus really is a door. And yet he's not. 

The point is that God knows things we can't even imagine. So in order to explain unknown concepts, one must use literary devices utilizing KNOWN concepts.

Every plant will emit CO2 since every true plant has cells that will have an organelle called a mitochondria.
In fact the only organisms without mitochondria are microscopic organisms like bacteria.
Mitochondria turn sugars (C6H12O6) (+ oxygen, O2) into water (H20) and carbon dioxide (CO2). Therefore, yes all plants will EMIT CO2. They just use up more than they emit so the net CO2 for plants is a reduction. 

Without a mitochondria, plants wouldn't be able to use the sugar they produce.

Trees actually do emit carbon dioxide. Trees and all other plants release CO2 at all times as they, like all living higher things, carry on respiration. These are known as "dark reactions" but more descriptive, non-light reactions or the Calvin cycle (aka light independent). There are a couple of interesting ways that CO2 is generated and used. Respiration is made possible by the production of foods threw photosynthesis which happens in light, hence, light dependent reactions.

Many college professors use the same methods to teach complicated ideas.
Often a professor will have a student explain ideas.
Even if the student is wrong, the professor won't tell them and just keep asking the student to explain further. In this method the student can often times realized their own error and solve it themselves. I believe it's based on a Socratic method of teaching.
In this way, the student learns far better then simply having the professor say, "You're wrong, the answer is..."

Ah, but therein lies a problem: QM =/= relativity. Einstein was famous for his "thought experiments", he explained certain consequences of relativity with hypothetical situations, using the simple and elegant postulates of relativity. Quantum mechanics only really postulates the Shrodinger (or Dirac) equasion, and the basics require some mathematical (like knowing what a differential equasion is) or physical (knowing what a field of potential energy is) background. This > target audience.
